contextId.information: This is an idiom that means "telling Yahweh my deepest emotions." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: pouring out my soul before Yahweh

contextId.information: Here the idiom "As you live" shows that Hannah is being sincere and truthful. AT: "Sir, what I am going to tell you is certainly true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Oh, my master! As you live, my master

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "I will cause a man to become priest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will raise up ... a faithful priest

contextId.information: Here "house" is an idiom used for "descendants." AT: "I will ensure that he always has a descendant who serves as high priest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will build him a sure house

contextId.information: This is an idiom to emphasize how serious Eli is. AT: "May God punish you the same way he said he will punish me, and even more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: May God do so to you, and even more

contextId.information: This is an idiom which means he was very fearful or terribly concerned about something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. "Yahweh severely judged" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "Yahweh punished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The words "by all means" are a forceful way of saying something. AT: "you must send a guilt offering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: by all means send him a guilt offering

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "looked up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The way a person lives is spoken of as walking on a path. AT: "do not do the things you do" or "do not do what is just the way you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: do not walk in your ways

contextId.information: God enabled Samuel to think differently from the way he had thought before. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

God touching a person's heart is an idiom that means God put something in their mind or moved them to do something. AT: "who wanted to go with Saul because God had changed their thinking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These expressions mean that people can actually see the kind of lives Saul and Samuel are living. AT: "the king's life was seen ... My life was seen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: the king walking before you ... I have walked before you

contextId.information: This is an idiom for "Samuel left and went up." (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This seems to be an idiom the means "Stop what you are doing." Saul did not want Ahijah to continue to use the ark to ask God for direction. AT: "Do not bring the sacred chest at this time" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means that he was strengthened. AT: "he regained his strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means he had disobeyed the commandment. AT: "I have disobeyed what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom refers to Yahweh, who gives strength to the Israelites. AT: "Yahweh, who is the strength of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This idiom appears to mean that Agag no longer thought he would be killed. AT: "Surely I am no longer in danger or dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Surely the bitterness of death has past

contextId.information: Here "with him" means Yahweh helps and blesses David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "stand before me" is an idiom that means to continue in Saul's service. AT: "Let David stay in my service" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "rose up against" is an idiom that refers to attacking. AT: "it attacked me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "the people" refers to the soldiers under David's command. The phrases "went out" and "came in" are idioms that refer to leading the people into battle and leading them home from battle. AT: "David led his soldiers into battle and led them home from battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: David went out and came in before the people

contextId.information: Here "stood in awe" is an idiom that means to fear. AT: "he feared David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: he stood in awe of him

contextId.information: The phrases "went out" and "came in" are idioms that refer to leading the people into battle and leading them home from battle. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:18:13|18:13]]. AT: "led his soldiers into battle and led them home from battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: went out and came in before them

contextId.information: Here "far from it" is an idiom that refers to that it is not true. AT: "This is certainly not true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "step between me and death" is an idiom that refers to being very close to death. AT: "I am very close to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: there is but a step between me and death

contextId.information: Here "business was in hand" is an idiom that refers to when everything happened. AT: "when everything happened" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: when the business was in hand

contextId.information: Here "Turn" means to turn around or turn away from the king. AT: "Go and kill" or "Kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

Here "Turn" means to turn around or turn away from the king. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:22:16|22:17]]. AT: "Go and kill the priests ... went and attacked" or "Kill the priest ... attacked the priests" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Turn and kill the priests ... turned and attacked the priests

contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "try to kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT "encouraged him to trust in God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "arose" is an idiom for taking action. AT: "David took action; he quietly crept" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "David was sad because he had done something wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "bread" is an idiom for any kind of food. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "house" is an idiom used for "descendants." AT: "Yahweh will ensure that my master always has a descendant who serves as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will certainly make my master a sure house

contextId.information: attacking and taking property many times (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom.  "As certainly as Yahweh lives" or "This is a true statement" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
